prompt.p: A 34-year-old woman presents with lower abdominal pain of sudden onset. There has been no nausea, vomiting or change in bowel habit. She is currently 2 weeks into her menstrual cycle. On examination her abdomen is soft with lower abdominal tenderness. Haematological investigation reveals:
An ultrasound scan reveals multiple cystic lesions of the ovaries and free fluid in the pelvis.
What medication is the cause of the patient's presentation?

modalFeedback.p: Option C (Clomifene) is Correct. Clomifene is used in the treatment of anovulatory infertility. This anti-oestrogen can cause ovarian hyperstimulation leading to lower abdominal pain.
Option A (Alendronate) is Incorrect. Is a bisphosphonate that is used in osteoporosis. Tablets can cause erosion of the gastrointestinal tract, e.g. oesophagitis or gastric ulceration.

Option B (Carbimazole) is Incorrect. Agranulocytosis is a complication of this medication used to treat hyperthyroidism. Patients are warned to seek medical attention if they become ill with symptoms and sign of infection.

Option D (Metformin) is Incorrect. Rarely can cause lactic acidosis which requires withdrawal of this treatment. It can occur in the presence of renal impairment, dehydration, shock, infection or myocardial infarction.

Option E (Octreotide) is Incorrect. Is used in acromegaly or down regulation of the exocrine pancreas after pancreatic surgery. This somatostatin analogue causes cholelithiasis and can result in gallstone formation.
